event.desc:
In
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
during the reign of Abgar the Great , the Daisan river flooded Edessa destroying the western wall of the city, the Great Palace , and the Church of the Christians .

personGrp.persName:
Workers in the government of Edessa in
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513

occupation.note: Anonymi 2210 were government officials in Edessa .

personGrp.persName:
The wise men of Edessa in
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513

event.desc:
In
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
, Abgar commanded the removal of the flood gates of Edessa .

personGrp.persName:
The two thousand people killed by flooding in Edessa in
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
.

event.desc:
Two thousand people were killed in Edessa by the flooding of the Daisan river
in
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
.

personGrp.persName:
The craftsmen of Edessa in
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
.

event.desc:
In
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
, Abgar commanded the craftsmen of Edessa
to remove their cottage from the banks of the Daisan river .

personGrp.persName:
The measurers and men of skill of Edessa in
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
.

occupation.note: Anonymi 2230 were skilled laborers in Edessa .

personGrp.persName:
Those who lived in the portico in Edessa in
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513

The islanders of Edessa in
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
.

occupation.note: The islanders were watchmen in Edessa .

event.desc:
In
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
, Abgar commanded those who live in the portico of Edessa not to lodge in their cottages during the winter.

After
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
, Abgar commanded to be built a royal house in Beth Tabara where he dwelt during the winters.

personGrp.persName:
The nobles of Abgar of Edessa in
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
.

occupation.note: These men were the nobles of Abgar in Edessa .

event.desc:
After
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
, Abgar remitted the taxes of Edessa and the surrounding towns for five years on account of the flood.

occupation.note: Mar Yahab Bar Shemesh was a scribe of Edessa .
Kaiuma Bar Magartat was a scribe of Edessa .
Bar Din was a prefect over the archives of Edessa .
Bulid was prefect over the archives of Edessa .

event.desc:
After
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
, Mar Yahab Bar Shemesh and Kaiuma Bar Magartat recorded the flooding of Edessa.

After
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513
, Bar Din and Bulid archived the record of the flooding of Edessa .

In
132/1 B.C.
A. Gr. 180
Kings began to rule in Edessa .

occupation.note: Augustus Caesar was king of Rome .

event.desc:
In
44 B.C.
46/5 B.C.
A. Gr. 266
Augustus became King of Rome .

div.note: The author has apparently mistaken the date of Augustus' accession.

event.desc:
Jesus was born in
3/2 B.C.

A. D. 88/9
A. Gr. 400
.

A. D. 137/8

.

personGrp.persName: The bishops assembled at the Second Council of Ephesus in A. D. 429

event.desc:
The bishops assembled at the Second Council of Ephesus anathematized Flavian of Constantinople , Domnus of Antioch
, Irenaeus of Tyre , Hiba of Edessa
, Eusebius of Dorylaeum
, Daniel of Ḥarran
, Sophronius of Tella , and Theodoret of Cyrrhus
.

div.note:
Since the first session of the Council of Chalcedon began on 8 October (Teshri I) of A. D. 451, the correct year A. Gr. would be 763, not 762.

many locusts appeared in Edessa and did little damage but layed eggs.

A. D. 498/9
A. Gr. 810
there was a great earthquake.

A. Gr. 810

A. D. 498/9

the Bishop of Nicopolis . and two synkelli survived an earthquake that destroyed Nicopolis

January A. D. 499
Kānun II A. Gr. 810
a sign like a spear appeared for many days in the sky above Edessa .

In
A. D. 498/9
A. Gr. 810

In
A. D. 498/9
A. Gr. 810
Macedon became Bishop of Constantinople after the deposition of Euphemius .

In
A. D. 499/500
A. Gr. 811
locusts devoured the grain of Edessa .

On
22 August A. D. 502
22 Āb A. Gr. 813
a great fire appeared in the north of the city of Edessa .

Kavad besieged the city of Amida
from 5 November A. D. 502 to 10 February A. D. 503
for 97 days beginning on 5 Teshri II A. Gr. 814

On
10 February A. D. 503
the 97th day after 5 Teshri II A. Gr. 814
Kavad captured the city of Amida .

In
September A. D. 503
Elul A. Gr. 814
Kavad besieged Edessa but did not capture it.

During the seige of Edessa
in
September A. D. 503
Elul A. Gr. 814
Kavad burned the House of Mar Sergius and the House of the Confessors .

orig.date: The Sabbath of the Resurrection A. Gr. 821

On

the Sabbath of the Resurrection A. Gr. 821

After
10 April A. D. 510
the Sabbath of the Resurrection A. Gr. 821
Pawlā became Bishop of Edessa .

In
A. D. 511/2 This regularized date was calculated by the SPEAR editor from a non-calendrical dating system such as regnal years, etc.
the 21st year of the reign of Anastasios
Anastasios commanded them to open the coffin of Euphemia the martyr , remove the book placed there by the Council of Chalcedon
, and burn it. Anastasios relented when fire from heaven struck the faces of those wishing to remove it .

personGrp.persName:
Those struck by fire in
A. D. 511/2 This regularized date was calculated by the SPEAR editor from a non-calendrical dating system such as regnal years, etc.
the 21st year of the reign of Anastasios
because they wanted to remove the book placed in the coffin of Euphemia the martyr by the Council of Chalcedon
.

event.desc:
In
A. D. 511/2 This regularized date was calculated by the SPEAR editor from a non-calendrical dating system such as regnal years, etc.
the 21st year of the reign of Anastasios
Anastasios deposed Macedon because he did not anathematize the Council of Chalcedon
.

In
A. D. 511/2 This regularized date was calculated by the SPEAR editor from a non-calendrical dating system such as regnal years, etc.
the 21st year of the reign of Anastasios

In

the 24st year of the reign of Anastasios

death.note: Anastasios died on 9 July A. D. 518.

event.desc:
On
9 July A. D. 518
9 Tammuz A. Gr. 829
Anastasios died.

After
9 July A. D. 518
9 Tammuz A. Gr. 829
Justin became King of Rome .

In
A. D. 499/500
A. Gr. 830
Justin deposed Severus and Philoxenos for refusing to accept the Council of Chalcedon
.

On
4 November A. D. 519
4 Teshri II A. Gr. 831
Patricius arrived in Edessa at the command of the Emperor Justin in order to urge Bishop Pawlā to receive the Council of Chalcedon
or else be deposed.

After
4 November A. D. 519
4 Teshri II A. Gr. 831
, Bishop Pawlā refused to accept the Council of Chalcedon
. When Patricius threatened to remove him from Edessa he fled to the House of Baptism . Fearing the command of Emperor Justin , Patricius removed Bishop Pawlā to Seleucia .

ptr.target: http://syriaca.org/keyword/bishop http://syriaca.org/keyword/councilChalcedon http://syriaca.org/keyword/bishop http://syriaca.org/keyword/deposition http://syriaca.org/keyword/synod http://syriaca.org/keyword/decree http://syriaca.org/keyword/exile

event.desc:
In
A. D. 520/1
A. Gr. 832
, the Emperor Justin returned Bishop Pawlā to his episcopal see in Edessa hoping that he would accept the Council of Chalcedon
.

Pawlā refused to accept the Council of Chalcedon
and on
27 July 27 A. D. 522
27 Tammuz A. Gr. 833
Emperor Justin deposed him and exiled him to Euchata .

Asclepius became bishop and entered the city of Edessa on
23 October A. D. 522
23 Teshri I A. Gr. 834
.

personGrp.persName:
The monks of the east in
24 December A. D. 522
24 Kānun I A. Gr. 834

event.desc:
In
24 December A. D. 522
24 Kānun I A. Gr. 834
Bishop Asclepius drove off the monks of the east because they would not accept the Council of Chalcedon
.

In
A. D. 524/5
A. Gr. 836
a flood destroyed Edessa for the fourth time.

death.note: Asclepius died on 27 June A. D. 525.

event.desc:
In
A. D. 424/5
A. Gr. 836
, after the flooding of Edessa
Asclepius fled Edessa and spent 70 days in Antioch with Euphrasius .

Asclepius died in Antioch on
27 June A. D. 525
27 Ḥazirān A. Gr. 836
.

On
4 September A. D. 525
4 Elul A. Gr. 836
they moved the body of Asclepius from Antioch to Edessa where he was buried alongside Nonos in the the House of Mar Barlāhā
.

After
27 June A. D. 525
27 Ḥazirān A. Gr. 836
, Pawlā repented of his opposition to the Council of Chalcedon
, petitioned Justinian for the return of his episcopal see, and wrote a libellus affirming the council to Euphrasius the Patriarch .

Following Pawlā's acceptance of the Council of Chalcedon
and a letter of support from Justinian , the Emperor Justin restored Pawlā to his episcopal see and he entered Edessa on
8 March A. D. 526
8 Ādar A. Gr. 837
.

death.note: Pawlā died on 30 October A. D. 526.

event.desc:
On
30 October A. D. 526
30 Teshri I A. Gr. 838
Pawlā died.

Andreos became bishop and entered the city of Edessa on
7 February A. D. 527
7 Shebāṭ A. Gr. 838
.

Justinian put into the diptychs of the church the four holy synods: the Council of Nicaea
, the Council of Constantinople , the Council of Ephesus
, and the Council of Chalcedon .

On
5 October A. D. 538
5 Teshri I A. Gr. 850
a sign like a spear appeared in the sky above Edessa .

On
29 May A. D. 526
29 Iyār A. Gr. 837
at the seventh hour a great earthquake struck Antioch .

On
15 November A. D. 527
15 Teshri II A. Gr. 839
a great fire of unknown origin burned much of what remained of Antioch after it was destroyed by earthquake .

death.note: Euphrasius died on 29 May A. D. 526.

event.desc:
On
29 May A. D. 526
29 Iyār A. Gr. 837
Euphrasius the Patriarch of Antioch
died in an earthquake.

occupation.note: Ephrem of Amida was Comes of the East .
Ephrem of Amida was Patriarch of Antioch .

event.desc:
After
29 May A. D. 526
29 Iyār A. Gr. 8371
Ephrem of Amida became Patriarch of Antioch .

death.note: Andreos died in December, A. D. 532.

event.desc:
In
December A. D. 532
Kānun I A. Gr. 844
Andreos died and was buried in the the House of Mar Barlāhā alongside the bones of Mar Nonos and Mar Asclepius

Addai became bishop and entered the city of Edessa on
28 August A. D. 533
28 Āb A. Gr. 844
.

On
1 April A. D. 527
1 Nisān A. Gr. 838
Justinian became Caesar.

On
10 August A. D. 527
10 Āb A. Gr. 838
Justinian became the sole King of Rome .

death.note: Justin died on 10 August A. D. 527.

event.desc:
On
10 August A. D. 527
10 Āb A. Gr. 838
Justin died.

personGrp.persName:
The Roman army commanded by Demosthenes in
July A. D. 531
Tammuz A. Gr. 842

event.desc:
In
July A. D. 531
Tammuz A. Gr. 842
Demosthenes arrived in Edessa to command the Roman army .

personGrp.persName:
The Huns who entered Roman territory on
18 December A. D. 531
18 Kānun I A. Gr. 843

event.desc:
On
18 December A. D. 531
18 Kānun I A. Gr. 843
the Huns entered Roman territory and plundered as far as the area around Aleppo and Antioch .

death.note: Demosthenes died on 10 January A. D. 532.

event.desc:
On
10 January A. D. 532
10 Kānun II A. Gr. 843
Demosthenes fell sick and died in Tella while fighting the the Huns .

In
September A. D. 532
Elul A. Gr. 843
Rufinus made peace between Rome , and Persia .

There was peace between Rome and Persia from
September A. D. 532 to May A. D. 540
Elul A. Gr. 843 to Iyār A. Gr. 851

person.persName: Chosroes the King of the Persians

event.desc:
In
May A. D. 540
Iyār A. Gr. 851
Chosroes broke the peace and invaded Roman territory . He laid waste Shura , Aleppo , and Antioch .

personGrp.persName:
The great men of the city of Edessa in
May A. D. 540
Iyār A. Gr. 851

event.desc:
After
May A. D. 540
Iyār A. Gr. 851
, the great men of the city of Edessa
saved the city from Chosroes by paying him two centenaria of gold, after which Chosroes returned to Persia .

The first time the walls of Edessa were broken down was in
November A. D. 201
Teshri II A. Gr. 513

The second time the walls of Edessa were broken down . was in the days of Diocletian the King in
May A. D. 303
Iyār A. Gr. 614

The third time the walls of Edessa were broken down was in the days of the Kings Honorios and Theodosius and of the bishop Rabbula in
March A. D. 413
Ādar A. Gr. 724
.

The fourth time the walls of Edessa were broken down was in the days of the king Justin and of the bishop Asclepius in
A. D. 424/5
A. Gr. 836

bibl.title: Stewards of the Poor: The Man of God, Rabbula, and Hiba in Fifth-Century Edessa
